No, no matter how wonderful my husband is, and he is, I prefer all of my rights and safety intact as much as possible. No, I was not given away by anyone. I'm not an object. Yes, my husband and I did have a fantastic wedding, our version of one. Did my husband or I change our names? Why would we? It's a complicated mess of paperwork. commentThread.commentText: What legal privileges do men have that women don't?
Fatty Bindel: Saltiest uggo on the planet

Marriage is about love, trust, and mutual consent. That is the modern definition, and the Bible supports this vision as well in the book Song of Solomon (one of my favorite books to read because it is all about love). The Bible also says "Husbands, love your wives, as Christ loved the Church and gave himself up for her" (Ephesians 5:25, ESV). It is true that there were traditions such as exchanging dowry and remaining a virgin until marriage that put certain interpretations and views upon marriage, but those traditions don't apply in the western world much anymore. When I think of marriage, I think of finding that one man in my life that I love and respect, the man who I can't nor want to live without, and the man who feels the same undying love for me that I feel for him. The reason I'm choosing to stay a virgin until marriage isn't because he would think I'm worthless if I didn't, but rather, a) I want sex to mean something more than 5 seconds of euphoria, and b) we BOTH decided it was the healthiest thing for our relationship, so we could base our compatibility on our emotional, intellectual, and spiritual compatibility. Essentially we are waiting to add the physical aspect that often blinds couples from the flaws in their relationships until after we've bonded more and worked through some of the kinks in our relationship. I also think it's absolutely absurd to think of marriage as enslavement or a prison in today's western society. We have all the freedom in the world (or at least the western world) to choose whether to commit ourselves to a man or leave him. No one is telling you that you have to get married. So why do you have to force this agenda down other women's throats, saying they are just "brainwashed" or "blinded"? Is it wrong to be in love with a man? Is it wrong to want to commit yourself to the one you love? Is it wrong to want to save yourself for that person, rather than give your body to just any man you think you could get a good bang out of? Marriage is a beautiful, wonderful gift from God and if a woman expects a man to be committed to her, she needs to be willing to commit to him and give him the same love and respect she desires. God Bless.

Some valid points about the horrific ways some other cultures use marriage as a means for oppression and inequality, but it's those examples that need to be considered, not the modern British marriage. I've spoken about marriage with my girlfriend and suggested we keep our own names, but she was adamant that she wanted to take mine - she said that we are a unit together. I understand the fact that she is taking MY name is indicative or perhaps even representative of an older, more unequal form of marriage, but it carries none of the same practical appliance today. You're right, this and also being given away by one's father are archaic, but in a modern context they don't seek to unbalance the relationship as they once did - they simply offer a sense of quaint tradition and an outlet for a specific form of heterosexual love. On the other side of the coin, there are plenty of women who are made uncomfortable by these ideas and choose to avoid them, and that's amazing and admirable. Also, I don't want to be 'that' guy (I broadly regard myself as a feminist) but I think many women (not all) look to men for a level of security and protection perhaps on a biological level, and it's upon this basis that some of these paradigms still remain (I've not done the research there, I'm happy to be debunked.) I think it's wonderful if a woman doesn't want to fit with the structures of the past, but it's not wrong for an active feminist to be motivated by their love for someone else or seek that unique sense of protection.

replies.commentText: It's not unconsciously sexist. Some of the traditions have been around for a very long time. Times are changing, and the traditions are catching up. Modern marriage is a legal union between two equals.

+imbecilik 
Marriage is built upon tradition - it can't divorce itself from its past

@Celestina As imaginative a statement as that may be, it is the ritual of the wedding that is set in tradition, not marriage. The concept of marriage -- or, I should say, the union of two people, and them committing to each other -- is a timeless idea, that is born out of the human condition.

@imbecilik
Bindel is clearly talking about the tradition of marriage as we understand it. She's not arguing against monogamous relationships without institutional backing.
This is a question of institution and tradition.

I would also like to question the idea that monogamous relationships as we understand them (and, more of a stretch, a 'marriage ritual') are 'born out of the human condition', I would like to see evidence for it. The fact that couples come together to have a child is not evidence for this; see: Mormon polygamy.

@Celestina She's saying that the concept of marriage -- in any way -- can never be what she wants it to be. Not as we understand it. As she sees it. And you question the idea of monogamous relationships being born from the human condition? First question I have for you: do you have children? The very nature of a sexual relationship, and the human urge to perform it, draws people together. When a child comes -- or is planned -- the parents need to commit to the relationship. In times past, if one ditched, the child died of starvation or being being unprotected. And polygamy? Well, a huge portion of the world is monogamous. There are polygamous communities. There are also people in our communities that like to "spread their seed". At its most basic, the purpose of life is to keep on producing life. The most practical means of doing that is to focus resources on a single partner, and one (in the case of humans) child at a time. It is how we have come to be...

@Celestina It is not "an appeal to nature". It is nature. Fact: to produce a child requires a mother and father. To raise that child requires commitment, otherwise the child won't survive. Marriage was our cultural way of enshrining that commitment required, making it binding in law (and before god), and not easily dissolved.

I see no moral problem with polygamy. But if a man has several wives, he also has to be able to provide for those wives (and eventual children). This takes a great deal of resources and (in modern society) money. Polygamy would have been a sign of prestige and power among the community. Average people would not have been quite so widely 

The monogamous relationship is the most simple of relationships. Simple in principle, and efficient in practice (because it is simple). The wider society is irrelevant when considering it is the two parents who are intended to raise the children.

Like I said, the cultural institution marriage has come about because of several factors. The modern marriage remains because people still fall in love, and want to commit themselves to being together -- the "human condition". That urge to be together, with a probable child (or children) in the future, ultimately would have brought a form of commitment promise. I.e., marriage.
@Lawrence Newman Thanks for the support, Lawrence, but I would consider myself a liberal. But I'm a liberal that appreciates facts. Please don't lump all liberals in with this SJW crowd.

+imbecilik Nobody's dying that two people are necessary to have a child. What I am challenging you to do is demonstrate that faithful monogamous relationships, 'enshrined' culturally in marriage rituals, are human nature. But I don't think you can. Human nature is an extremely nebulous concept. But then demanding evidential standards is what loony SJWs tend to do

I agree with you Morgan Roete, that the focus of feminist discussion shoudn't be about whether men feel accused/targeted/excluded. But it is a fair point from ugaaa5. I'm divided: I don't think concessions should be made so that men will feel comfortable, but on the other hand if men are included, wouldn't that be a good thing? I suppose the onus is on men to get beyond that feeling of being accused, to accept like wellybeana says that the patriarchal system is one that we've benefitted from. A bit of swallowing one's pride can be very healthy. I also think that JB is being deliberately provocative, because it's important that we as a society are having these discussions. She isn't saying that every woman in a loving marriage is being oppressed. But I think the system does need to be changed, and we need to throw off any vestiges of patriarchal symbolism. However, ugaaa5, I'm going to have to disagree with you on arranged marriages. Forced marriage is one thing, but I don't see a worse problem with arranged marriages than there is with Western (or otherwise non-arranged) marriages. If you have any Muslim friends you should ask them about it (since most Muslims practice arranged marriages). It's certainly very different, but I don't think it's necessarily a bad thing. You do get a choice, you know. Plus if you meet someone you'd like to marry, generally you will be able to marry them. (I'm sure some horrendous situations exist where this isn't the case.) It's just that the parents of the couple are much more involved than in other marriage systems. And that can really help to build a stable relationship between the two families. Get back to me; I'm interested in what you think.
